body:
Thanks a lot for the kind words :) Also, sorry for the delay in coming to this.

As you suggest it is related with #132 and the fix thereof. But your case is different and broader. 

**Regarding validation split**, (question 1) currently there is no option to input multiple arrays (which is the #132 case and the fix thereof). But that will deal with just the aspect of being able to pass a list of arrays, and might not resolve your case specifically. To say about that, I'd have to see first what is inside create_model(), train(), and evaluate() in your code. (question 2) The validation split itself you can handle through Scan() where you have the option for inputting x_val and y_val as argument. When you do that, there is no other splitting involved.

Thanks for the suggestions. Once 0.4.5 gets to pypi which should happen in the next few days, I'll do a full pass on the manual to make sure it's 100% up-to-date. 

**So what is reduction_metric?** It's the metric (e.g. 'val_acc') the reduction is performed based on. For example, when the optimization algorithm is spearman rank order, the correlation is performed "against" reduction_metric.

issue.title: add custom error message to when downsampling ends with < 1 sample

repository.name: talos
repository.description: Hyperparameter Optimization for TensorFlow, Keras and PyTorch

issue.body:
from #145:

"If grid_downsample is too low a Python IndexError will be thrown. Maybe it would be better to have a Talos error message explaining what is happening"

body:
All right, thank you for the answer! 

For now, I think I will try out scikit-optimize, which is hopefully a bit more flexible w.r.t. to inputs, but I will definitely keep an eye on this project in the future. 

I think scikit-optimize's approach (as I currently understand it) of not fiddling with the inputs/outputs of the model at all, is nice and simple. There (it seems) you simply define a function that takes params from a set search space, and returns any real number (which could be the validation loss of some custom metric) that the minimizer then attempts to minimize by inputting different params. 
Aside from the train_val_split functionality in Talos, what is the reason that the `Scan` method has to know anything about what the data (`x,y`) is? Is it integral to some core functionality of Talos? Is it for instance used when reducing the parameter space?

PS. Please take the above both as (hopefully) constructive critique and as an expression of me wanting to understand how Talos works, and what it does fundamentally different from e.g. scikit-optimize.

issue.title: Modification to run with multi-output models

labels.name: topic: data
labels.description: Has to do with input or output data

repository.name: talos
repository.description: Hyperparameter Optimization for TensorFlow, Keras and PyTorch

issue.body:
It would be great if possible to allow the option of using multi-output Keras models. 

It is currently stated in Scan.py that y should have shape (m, c) where c is the number of classes. This restricts to one output parameter and inputting a multi-output model yields the following error:
~/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/talos/scan/scan_prepare.py in scan_prepare(self)
     57 
     58     # create the data asset
---> 59     self.y_max = self.y.max()
     60     self = validation_split(self)
     61     self.shape = classify(self.y)

AttributeError: 'list' object has no attribute 'max'

For example the model I am currently working with outputs Age, Species, and Status where each has a different value of c in the shape (m, c).

body: Multi-input (list) models is now supported as of v.0.4.8. See #155 for more information. Closing here. Feel free to open a new issue if anything.
When this is going to be in master? I want to use it in ML-Engine but i can install a version over 0.4.5 and a I need the v.0.4.8. Thanks

@fgvenegas 

Why not you do: 

```
pip install -U git+https://github.com/autonomio/talos@daily-dev
```
You will then end up with v.0.4.8

@mikkokotila 

Maybe I'm wrong, but to install a library in ML-Engine you have to specify it like this:
```
REQUIRED_PACKAGES = ['Keras>=2.2.4',  'tensorflow-gpu==1.11']
```
So, in that case I only can install v0.4.5
Ah ok, I get it now. Let me look into this and report back later today. I think there is nothing stopping us from pushing to production up until v.0.4.8.

issue.title: How do I pass in a list of inputs?

repository.name: talos
repository.description: Hyperparameter Optimization for TensorFlow, Keras and PyTorch

issue.body:
In most talos code examples, X input seems to be a 2D numpy array.
But in some of my keras models, it requires a list of 2D numpy arrays because my models are not `Sequential`.
Example list: `[numpyarray1, numpyarray2, numpyarray3]`.

It seems that when I try to pass this list to the `ta.Scan` function, things break.

How do I pass in a list of inputs?

Also, I'm not sure if `talos` supports `pandas` DataFrame or not. But I think it does not support so please do make support for it.
